item.note: A soldier holding a battle-axe hands a spear to an Irish chieftain in full dress, with a page holding the chieftain's horse

"This plate gives a vivid picture of the Woodkarne and their costume" Small, 1883. "An Irish chieftain is represented in full dress, beside him is a man with a battle-axe in his hand, and a boy holding the horse of the chief" Small, 1883. It contains a title page on the left-hand side marking "A notable discovery most lively describing the state and condition of the Wilde men in Ireland, properly called Woodkarne." Names Day's print house at the bottom of the title description.
An armed company of the kerne, carrying halberds and pikes and led by a piper, attack and burn a farmhouse and drive off the horses and cattle
The most famous plate of the set shows the chief of the Mac Sweynes seated at dinner and being entertained by a bard and a harper

A wooden cut, representing these scenes of festivity, is almost torn out. Upon the remaining part, the following imperfect lines are found : "———yes the ape, by counterfeiting Paul: ——— ———rd him then the highest roome of all: ——— the cheere, is deemed little worth ———intermixt, and lae'de with Irishe myrth. ———[h]arper is preparde, which by their cunning art, ———[c]heare up all the gestes with comfort at the hart."

Scott was lilekly working with the NLS copy, which includes 8 of the 12 plates tipped in and interspersed within the poem. In this copy plate 3 is severely damaged.
This plate includes comic book elements like the suggestion of a speech bubble for the two farting men. A similar approach can be seen on place 7.

On the right-most edge of the illustration, two men bend over with their buttocks pointing at the a burning fire, as if to fart in its direction. A floating couplet typeset perpenducular to the two reads: "Aspice spectator sic me docuere parentes/Me quoque maiores omnes virtute carentes." The placement of the text next to the two figures suggests it is intended to behave as a "speech bubble" akin to a comic book dialogue. Each line belongs to man standing next to it. .
The Irish chieftain receives the priest's blessing before departing to fight the English, who are shown in full armour

"There is here a print which represents, at the lower left-hand corner, the friar, in a shaggy or rug mantle, blessing the Irish chief, who, having reverently laid aside his leathern helmet, chequered with bars of iron, and his large broadsword, receives the benediction on one knee. At the upper corner the benediction is repeated, the chief stooping from his horse to receive it ere he departs. In the centre is represented the chief and his party. He is on horseback, and the rest on foot, armed with pikes and swords. He wears the helmet formerly mentioned, which resembles a mitre, and his leathern quilted jacke appears beneath his shaggy mantle. In the up™ per corner, on the left hand, is the skirmish, in which the English soldiers, dressed in corslets and trunk-hose, and armed with calivers, are putting the kerne to flight. Beneath, two retainers are bearing off the body of the chief." Scott, 1809, 593.
